item.title: BAG Instructors
item.description: BAG Instructors Below are pictures of some of the people who helped put together and run the Build-a-Genome course. Eric Cooper Currently Associate Professor of Biology, [Hartwick College] Jessica Dymond Currently Vice President, Technology, at B.Next / In-Q-Tel Heloise Muller Currently Tenured Research Scientist, l’Institut Curie Lisa Scheifele Currently Chair, Department of Biology, Loyola University Maryland Giovanni Stracquadanio Currently UKRI EPSRC Fellow and Senior Lecturer in Synthetic Biology, University of Edinburgh

item.title: Franchising Build a Genome
item.description: Franchising Build a Genome The Build-A-Genome course has been franchised at multiple institutions. In the United States, B-A-G is taught at Loyola University (Baltimore, MD) and Hartwick College, and courses are being planned at North Carolina State University. In China, Tianjin University has used the B-A-G China course to build synthetic DNA corresponding to chromosomes syn5 and syn10. If you are interested in leading a B-A-G course, the BAG Network can provide information.

item.title: Course Description
item.description: Course Description The Build-A-Genome (B-A-G) Course was introduced in 2007, and is now offered for up to 20 students each semester and during the summer. To date, about 200 students have completed the course, including students majoring in computer science, biomedical engineering, biology, chemical and bio-molecular engineering, and biophysics. Entering students are interviewed to evaluate their understanding of the Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR), DNA cloning and sequencing, nucleic acid structure, biopolymer synthesis, and more before acceptance.
